poem:
Title: The Flickering Flame

In the wings of her youth, 
Cara spun,
a luminescent flame.
Model, actress, bold in truth,
a comet, briefly in frame.
Now, the hot new thing recedes,
eclipsed by the public's fickle gaze,
her star transforms, adapts, concedes,
no longer bound in the blaze.
From radiant warmth to gentle ember,
they watch, we watch, all remember.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cara Delevingne: ‘It’s a lot easier now I’m not the new hot young thing’ London-born Cara Delevingne, 31, began modelling in her teens and was twice model of the year at the British fashion awards. She started her acting career in Joe Wright’s 2012 film adaptation of Anna Karenina. Subsequent big screen roles include Paper Towns, Suicide Squad, Tulip Fever and London Fields. On TV, she has starred in Carnival Row, Only Murders in the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
